message: I'm working on a convore thing. Right now, its just fetching some json, eventually I think it'll be a bot framework.
Haha, sounds cool. I actually need to take apart my FluidDB (now "Fluidinfo") library and make it more idiomatic.
Are you planning on putting it on Github/something similar when you're done?
I have extra hoops to go through at work if I do some sort of open source stuff, but I'll likely do it because I want to show-off Go to my buddies :)
Ah, fair enough. I'll keep an eye out for it. :)
I figure I'm going to have each topic live as a goroutine, then have them pass the messages back to an arbiter via channels, who will contain the business logic.
We'll see how that actually pans out.
I've been working on a campfire bot (very slow progress because it's such a pain debugging https APIs) and a code stats collecting tool (to record programmer error rate - early days).
@wjlroe That sounds interesting. Working in private/github? I'd like to check it out.

@micrypt code stats is called arya (https://github.com/wjlroe/arya ) very early stages so far, but fun. The campfire bot (which I got working the other day, yay! isn't public, it's in a fossil repo on my VPS. It's fossil because I like being different :p
@micrypt yay! I'd better get to work then ;) Let me know if there's anything you think would make it useful

I was working on "chat-like case solving web system". The server is written in Go and the client in HTML5 and Javascript. They communicate through websocket. I quit developing it, but the base is already written: http://code.google.com/p/gocase/
I just finished up a small web framework thingy. Small view engine and routing, that works on AppEngine and fcgi. It was a good experience to learn the language :)

http://code.google.com/p/pokemon-universe/ -> an mmorpg programmed in Go I've contributed a (very) little by far, but take a look at the code. You can use it to program a game with Go (the sdl package is a binding for SDL 1.3)
